questions.question: How many variable types do we have in JavaScript?
Which of the types are primitive?

questions.question: What are object prototypes?

questions.b: A new way to extract elements from an object or an array.

questions.question: What is an Immediately Invoked Function in JavaScript?
questions.a: Behaviour that occurs with variables declared using let and const keywords. It is a behaviour where we try to access a variable before it is initialized.
questions.b: A function that runs as soon as it is defined.
questions.c: A syntactic sugars for constructor functions
questions.d: String, Boolean, Number, undefined, null, Symbol

questions.question: What is the role of deferred scripts in JavaScript?
questions.a: Your page will be affected if your network is a bit slow, or if the script is very hefty.
questions.b: Speeds up the usage of your project, if your Network is shit
questions.c: the script waits for the HTML parser to finish before executing it.

questions.question: What are callbacks?
questions.a: A function that will be executed after another function gets executed.
questions.c: A technique to iterate over an operation by having a function call itself repeatedly until it arrives at a result.
questions.d: A form of caching where the return value of a function is cached based on its parameters.

questions.question: What is currying in JavaScript?
questions.a: An advanced technique to transform a function of arguments n, to n functions of one or fewer arguments.
questions.b: An ability of a function to remember the variables and functions that are declared in its outer scope.
questions.c: A technique to iterate over an operation by having a function call itself repeatedly until it arrives at a result.
questions.d: A form of caching where the return value of a function is cached based on its parameters.

questions.question: What is memoization?
questions.a: A function that will be executed after another function gets executed.
questions.c: A technique to iterate over an operation by having a function call itself repeatedly until it arrives at a result.
questions.d: A form of caching where the return value of a function is cached based on its parameters.

questions.question: What are arrow functions?
questions.b: A new and shorter syntax for declaring functions.
questions.c: A form of caching where the return value of a function is cached based on its parameters.
questions.d: A technique to iterate over an operation by having a function call itself repeatedly until it arrives at a result.

questions.question: What are the feature of Python?
questions.c: Writing Python code is quick but running it is often slower than compiled languages.

questions.question: What is slicing in Python?
questions.a: It's used to access parts of sequences like lists, tuples, and strings.
questions.b: A naming system used to make sure that names are unique to avoid naming conflicts.

questions.question: What is monkey patching?
questions.a: Refers to dynamic modifications of a class or module at run-time.
questions.b: A special library, where all focused on monkey is.

questions.question: What is polymorphism in Python?
questions.a: It's another subdivision of the built-in dict class.
questions.b: It is a set of rules that specify how to format Python code for maximum readability.
questions.c: An environment variable, which is used when a module is imported.
